Other News - RBA watcher McCrann suggested don't be so sure regarding the RBA cutting rates 4 times, while he added that the RBA has not yet cut once but commentators are rushing to be the first to predict the most cuts in shortest possible time. (Herald Sun)

Other News - Most bond experts anticipate the BoK to maintain its benchmark rate at 1.75% at its meeting on Friday with 97% of the 200 surveyed expecting a hold in policy. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Secretary of State Pompeo stated that Huawei is an instrument of the Chinese Government and that US may or may not get a trade deal with China. (Newswires/Fox Business News)

China’s Global Times Editor said US crackdown on Chinese Co.s including Huawei is no longer like a trade war and the US is shifting from protecting its interest to destroying China, while China are mulling qualitative change in countermeasures. (Twitter)

Huawei suggested as many as 1200 US suppliers could be hit by the Trump administration's blacklisting of the Chinese telecoms company. (FT)

 

UK/EU

Irish PM Varadkar stated that there could be a potential extension of Brexit in October and that alternative options could be a hard Brexit or No-Brexit. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn (Neutral) said the Eurozone is seeing a soft patch although he doesn’t expect a recession at the moment. Rehn also commented that the first hike is further away now than it was a couple of months ago and reinvestment of maturing bonds will continue beyond first hike, while TLTRO details are to be discussed next week. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini said he is not in favour of a snap election and wants to work with 5SM but will not accept a situation similar to that of the past few weeks. (Newswires)

EU letter to Italy confirmed that Italy risks disciplinary process due to its debt. (Newswires)

 

FX

Bank of Canada Rate Decision 1.75% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%). BoC made no mention of returning to neutral range and stated that recent data has reinforced governing council's view that late 2018 slowdown was temporary, while it added that trade restrictions having direct effect on Canadian exports. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories -5.27mln vs. Exp. -0.9mln (Prev. +2.4mln). (Newswires) Iranian crude oil exports have fallen to around 400k BPD in May (vs. 970k in April), according to Refinitiv data and industry sources. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian President Rouhani said the door to discussions with the US is not closed as long as they lift sanctions on Iran and fulfil their commitments, while there were separate comments from the Iran Supreme Leader Khamenei that Iran will not negotiate with the US and will use military pressure if needed. (Newswires)

US State Department said it is alarmed that Russia continues to disregard its international arms control obligation which follows earlier reports that Russia is conducting low yield nuke tests. (Newswires)

 

US

US House Speaker Pelosi said she still thinks President Trump wants to do an infrastructure deal. (Newswires)

US Special Counsel Mueller announced he is resigning and formally closing the office. Mueller stated that if we had confidence the President clearly did not commit a crime, we would have said so but added we did not, however, make a determination as to whether the President did commit a crime, while he also commented that charging the President was not an option. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Financial names, including Citi Group (C), Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), were broadly lower as yields extended their march lower, with some financial newswires also citing worries about declining trading volumes and economic health. Energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP), were also broadly lower, as WTI crude fell on the day. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) moved lower amidst a spike in the price of avocados and corn in the US due to bad weather. Apple (AAPL) were under pressure following a Washington Post investigation, which found that many iOS apps use the iPhone’s background refresh feature to send data (such as location and IP address) to third-party tracker companies. Boeing (BA) also moved lower following a flurry of bad headlines, including news that Ethiopian Airlines pilot von Hoesslin told senior managers at the airline that additional training and improved communication to crew members was needed, several months prior to the first Boeing (BA) 737 Max crash. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) shares moved lower against the backdrop of continued public scrutiny, in which the drug maker is facing a large number of court cases for allegedly fuelling the opioid epidemic. Workday (WDAY) shares sunk despite the co beating on both top and bottom lines and revising its FY20 view for subscriptions earnings higher. Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) were under lower as an active investor group plans to nominate new board members was thwarted. Arcelor Mittal (MT) shares moved lower after the firm announced plans to reduce production in Europe in line with market demand. Tesla (TSLA) saw choppy price action, moving as much as 2% higher and lower on the day, amidst reports that the electric automaker is to reorganise their operations at their California Gigafactory. S&P 500 -0.7% at 2783, Dow Jones -0.9% at 7217, NASDAQ-100 -0.9% at 25126.

The T-plex continued its rally during the European session before paring back gains going into settlement. Looking at the curve, the 2s/10s steepened by c. 1.8bps, with the 5s/30s flattening by c. 1bps. The 7-year auction was relatively weak, where it tailed by 1.9bps, above the six-auction average of -0.3bps, and the B/C ratio came in at 2.3x, below the six-auction averages of 2.53x. It is worth highlighting that the high-yield was the lowest it has been since September 2017, coming amidst a sharp rally in bonds in recent sessions. In regard to the breakdown, dealers took a chunky 30%, almost double the six-auction average, with discretionary buyers (indirects/directs) both taking below averages. In the fallout from the auction Treasuries sold off, with newswires attributing dealers as the main sellers as they seek to offload their large holdings. US T-note futures (M9) settled 7+ ticks higher at 125-20.

US MARKET WRAP – 29th MAY 2019: BoC removes mention of neutral rate; US adds China to currency watch list
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries flat, Dollar higher, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: BoC hold rates, removes reference to returning to neutral rate, US releases Currency Manipulation report; adds China and others to watchlist, Iran says will not negotiate with the West, EU sends letter to Italy on debt, Plenty of ECB speak (incl. ECB head hopeful Rehn), weak German employment data

* COMING UP: AU Building Approvals, SP HICP Flash, US GDP 2nd Estimate, Advanced Goods Trade, Initial Jobless Claims, Weekly Crude Stocks, BoJ’s Sakurai, Fed’s Clarida, BoC’s Wilkins, US VP Pence to meet Canada PM Trudeau on USMCA

* BOC: The BOC kept rates unchanged at 1.75%, as was unanimously expected. The key takeaway was that the BOC made no mention of returning rates to neutral in its policy statement (it estimated neutral at between 2.25-3.25% at its previous MPR meeting), signalling that the BOC is now in pause mode. “The Bank had already shifted to the dovish side but the tone of the accompanying statement was a little more optimistic than the April meeting,” Rabobank said, “That said, there was no shift back to a tightening bias and the Bank maintained a data-watch stance.” The general language of the Bank was upbeat, arguing that earlier weakness was temporary; trade restrictions were having an impact on Canadian exports and trade risks have increased, it said. The bank also said current degree of accommodation remains appropriate. Market pricing for the trajectory of BOC rate moves was pretty-much unchanged (around half a rate cut priced by the end of the year). “This meeting did little to alter our view that the BOC is too optimistic about activity prospects looking forward and we maintain the view that the BOC will begin easing in Q2 2020,” Rabo said.

* TRADE: A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said on Wednesday that the US is not in a position to decide which countries manipulates currency. This came after the US Treasury said no major trading partner met currency manipulation list but added that China, amongst several others, had been added to the “monitoring list”. In the US, Secretary of State Pompeo said the US may or may not get a trade deal with China, he also said that Huawei is a instrument of the Chinese Government (a well-established US stance). The China Global Times Editor weighed in as usual on the matter, tweeting that the “US is shifting from protecting its interests to destroying China… China is mulling qualitative change in countermeasures.” In an apparent response to the threat that China may weaponize rare earth mineral exports to the US; a Pentagon spokesperson said they had submitted a report on rare-earth minerals to congress and the US will seek to reduce reliance on China.

* TREASURY SEMI-ANNUAL FX REPORT: Released a month late, the report did not name any country (China) a currency manipulator. However, it added Ireland, Italy, Vietnam, Singapore and Malaysia to its monitoring list, which already includes China, Japan, South Korea and Germany. Switzerland and India have been removed from the monitoring list, as was expected. The Treasury also expanded the number of US trading partners covered in the report from 12 to 21. A key takeaway was that the Treasury adjusted its three criteria for judging whether a nation is a currency manipulator (indeed, the Treasury justified the delay due to changes to the criteria); two of the thresholds that the Treasury uses were revised lower (current account balance criteria lowered to 2%/GDP vs 3% previously), and persistence of net FX purchases (lowered to six out of 12 months vs eight out of 12 months previously). The report, however, unsurprisingly remained critical of China (which only met one of the three criteria), and the nation remains at the top of the monitoring list; The Treasury stated that “China’s persistent and widespread use of non-tariff barriers, non market mechanisms, state subsidies, and other discriminatory measures that are increasingly distorting China’s trading and investment relationships” to “refrain from engaging in competitive devaluation and to not target China’s exchange rate for competitive purposes.” The Treasury recommitted to continuing bilateral engagement with China.

* UK POLITICS: UK Judge says MP, and potential PM candidate, Boris Johnson must attend court for a preliminary hearing regarding allegations of misconduct in a public office. This news followed prior reports that Boris Johnson lied & was involved in criminal conduct when he claimed during the 2016 EU Referendum that the UK sent GBP 350mln per week to the EU.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Middle-East tensions were again in the spotlight on Wednesday, US President Trump’s hawkish National Security Advisor Bolton has claimed the recent attacks on Saudi tankers off the UAE were caused by Iranian naval mines, and Iranian Supreme leader Khamenei later threatened the use of military pressure against the US “if needed”. Elsewhere, the US has suggested that Russia is likely conducting low-yield Nuke tests, which if so, would be in violation of the treaty on banning nuclear tests.

* ITALY: Tensions between Italy and the EU continue. Early reports suggested that the Five Star Movement was to vote on whether to continue with Di Maio as leader; Di Maio was also reportedly seeking support from Deputy PM Salvini to maintain current government coalition. Italian Deputy PM Salvini commented that he is not in favour of a snap election and wants to work with 5SM but will not accept a situation similar to that of the past few weeks - a sign that he will try and leverage the League's strong performance at the European elections in an effort to change government policy, before he mulls fresh elections. Turning his attention to the EU, regarding a potential EU request for a budget correction, Salvini reiterated that the Italian Government will definitely never increase taxation. Shortly after, the EU sent a letter to Italy, publicly confirming that the country risks disciplinary process due to its debt (this comes in the context of reports on Monday that Italy could face a EUR 3.5bln fine from the European Commission unless they curb their debt levels).

* ECB: The ECB Financial Stability Report stated that challenges to financial stability are increasing amid downside risks to the economic outlook, that economic recovery in the Euro area has been delayed but not derailed, and corporate bond markets and liquidity conditions remain fragile despite bond price recovery in 2019. ECB’s Mersch (Hawkish) commented that, as central banks should remain true to the core mandate, whilst also saying the capacity to adapt to evolving needs must be retained, but this must not come at the expense of independence or accountability. ECB's Vice President De Guindos (Neutral) commented that trade wars are the main threat to the economic environment and that the implementation of counter-cyclical buffers in some countries is appropriate. He said that the problem for Italy is low growth and any controversy between the Govt. and the Commission on fiscal rules is reflected in spreads, and should be respected. Speaking on ECB policy moving forward, ECB's Rehn (Neutral) noted that the first hike is further away now than it was a couple of months ago, that the reinvestment of maturing bonds will continue beyond first hike and TLTRO details to be discussed next week. He also noted that an ample degree of monetary policy stimulus is appropriate at present. Rehn said that it is no secret they have discussed the impact of negative rates, but unconventional measures have clearly been positive. On ECB strategy, Rehn said that the ECB should review its monetary policy strategy in the medium and long term, and that at some point a strategy review is needed, but he would not touch the ECB mandate. He said that the ECB needs credible guidance and for it to be backed up if necessary, and suggested that the ECB should look at the definition of price stability as, in his view, 2% is not a ceiling. On trade and the economy, he said that he sees little impact on inflation from trade tensions, and that the Eurozone is seeing a soft patch and doesn't see a recession at the moment. Regarding the idea of the ECB guaranteeing government debt, Rehn noted central banks are forbidden from monetary financing. Finally, Rehn commented that nationality should not play a role in deciding the incoming ECB President. It is worth noting that Rehn is seen as the compromise candidate between Germany and France.

* GERMAN DATA: German Unemployment rose to 5.0% in May (from 4.9% in April), higher than the expected 4.9%. Unemployment claims jumped to 60k (from a 12k fall in April), also much higher than the expected 8k fall. Pantheon Macroeconomics comment “the enormous 60K leap in unemployment claims–the biggest since 2009—is partly due to a re-classification of workers” but also but caveat that “the Federal Labor Agency still estimates that unemployment claims, corrected for this one-off hit, rose by 10-to-15K.” This corrected numbers still marks a sharp departure from the expected, which Pantheon does not find surprising. In that regard, the consultancy notes “German GDP growth has slowed sharply in recent quarters; the PMIs have been warning about falling employment in manufacturing and the IAB’s unemployment index has deteriorated. We think today’s report could well be the beginning of a more sustained increase in German jobless claims, though the trend will be have to be corrected for the May headline as we move along.” Regarding the German labour market, Pantheon conclude “the solid German employment picture will not spontaneously combust this year, but the rate of improvement will deteriorate significantly, reflecting the gruelling slowdown in manufacturing.” Of note: Pantheon have warnings for those tempted to buy bonds based on these headlines, saying this may not prove to be the right trade; “If the improving trend in the labour market is now stalling, the government will be pushed even more strongly towards some form of fiscal stimulus and public investment; both of these, presumably, would require debt issuance”.

* US T-Note futures (M9) settled 7+ ticks higher at 125-20: The T-plex continued its rally during the European session before paring back gains going into settlement. Looking at the curve, the 2s/10s steepened by c. 1.8bps, with the 5s/30s flattening by c. 1bps. The 7-year auction was relatively weak, where it tailed by 1.9bps, above the six-auction average of -0.3bps, and the B/C ratio came in at 2.3x, below the six-auction averages of 2.53x. It is worth highlighting that the high-yield was the lowest it has been since September 2017, coming amidst a sharp rally in bonds in recent sessions. In regard to the breakdown, dealers took a chunky 30%, almost double the six-auction average, with discretionary buyers (indirects/directs) both taking below averages. In the fallout from the auction Treasuries sold off, with newswires attributing dealers as the main sellers as they seek to offload their large holdings.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.33 LOWER AT USD 58.81/BBL; BRENT (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.66 LOWER AT USD 69.45/BBL: Following Tuesday’s indecisiveness regarding the crude market’s direction, a drop-in risk appetite saw it trade decisively in the red through the majority of Wednesday’s session, before paring some losses into settlement. Slowing global growth and a lack of upside demand catalysts have seen Treasury yields continue their march lower, with the 3m/10y exacerbating its inversion, consequentially spooking risk assets. Although less in vogue, there has been some supply-side updates, which ultimately failed to reverse crude’s losses. Iranian crude oil exports have reportedly dropped to 400k BPD in May (vs. 970k BPD in April, although it was said to be producing at a clip of 250K at the beginning of May), however, prior reports suggested tankers were simply turning off their transponders during transit. Elsewhere, following Russia previously expressing discomfort to an extension of the OPEC+ supply cuts, Russian First Deputy PM Anton Siluanov said that the key supplier is now open to the possibility, where it will evaluate the trade-off between higher prices and a loss of market share to the US. It is worth noting that the API US inventory data will be released on Wednesday, a day later due to market closures during Memorial Day. Current expectations see crude stocks drawing 0.9mln bbls; gasoline stocks drawing -0.5mln bbls; distillates building 0.6mln bbls. Elsewhere in the US, WTI front-end contango has been increasing amidst a slew of US pipeline closures as a result of severe flooding in the Mid-West, sparking “predictions of swelling oil stocks at Cushing”, PVM analysts note, elevating risks of a national supply glut just as producers head into key summer runs. If the supply disruptions were to materialise in Cushing stocks, it’s worth noting this would not be evident until next week’s inventory release due to the backward-looking nature of the data.

* S&P 500 -0.7% at 2783, Dow Jones -0.9% at 7217, NASDAQ-100 -0.9% at 25126; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.9%, Consumer Staples -0.7%, Energy  -0.6%, Financials -0.1%, Health Care -1%, Industrials -0.5%, Information Technology -0.6%, Materials -0.1%, Telecommunication Services -1.1%, Utilities -1.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Financial names, including Citi Group (C), Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), were broadly lower as yields extended their march lower, with some financial newswires also citing worries about declining trading volumes and economic health. Energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP), were also broadly lower, as WTI crude fell on the day. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) moved lower amidst a spike in the price of avocados and corn in the US due to bad weather. Apple (AAPL) were under pressure following a Washington Post investigation, which found that many iOS apps use the iPhone’s background refresh feature to send data (such as location and IP address) to third-party tracker companies. Boeing (BA) also moved lower following a flurry of bad headlines, including news that Ethiopian Airlines pilot von Hoesslin told senior managers at the airline that additional training and improved communication to crew members was needed, several months prior to the first Boeing (BA) 737 Max crash. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) shares moved lower against the backdrop of continued public scrutiny, in which the drug maker is facing a large number of court cases for allegedly fuelling the opioid epidemic. Workday (WDAY) shares sunk despite the co beating on both top and bottom lines and revising its FY20 view for subscriptions earnings higher. Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) were under lower as an active investor group plans to nominate new board members was thwarted. Arcelor Mittal (MT) shares moved lower after the firm announced plans to reduce production in Europe in line with market demand. Tesla (TSLA) saw choppy price action, moving as much as 2% higher and lower on the day, amidst reports that the electric automaker is to reorganise their operations at their California Gigafactory.

* FX WRAP: USD: DXY broke back above the 98.00 handle, with gains capped as the index formed a double top at 98.20. The greenback caught a bid vs Yen on yield differentials as a soft 7-year action triggered USTs to sell off somewhat. CAD was weaker on the day, as the market anticipated the BoC to err on the side of dovish; to which the BoC obliged, removing any reference of a return to the neutral range in its statement. EUR was under pressure throughout the day; with weak German employment data and warnings from the US that their Iran efforts may face sanctions doing little to help, as well as the backdrop of growing Italy/EU debt tensions (the EU confirming its intentions to look into sanctions). JPY was stronger vs the majority of its G10 counterparts (apart from the dollar), as global risk assets sold off. GBP followed EUR lower (with guilt yields also reaching fresh 2-year lows). SEK was strong as Swedish GDP beat expectations by a wide margin, giving further credence to the Riksbank’s hawkish bias. NOK, however, was weaker as the crude complex came off. ZAR strengthened on the day, catching a bid in later trade as President Ramaphosa announced a new, smaller cabinet. BRL was also strong, breaking back below 4.00 vs USD, with reports that the BCB would be soon announcing capital markets measures as soon as next week supportive.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 32bln of 7-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction a total of USD 131bln in new 2-year (USD 40bln, Tue), new 5-year (USD 41bln, also on Tue), and new 7-year (USD 32bln, Wed), as well as a 2-year FRN re-opening (USD 18bln, Wed). UBS notes that there are USD 81bln of cash flows this week (including USD 73bln of redemptions + USD 8bln of coupons) falling due, implying net supply at around USD 50bln.   

* RECENT AUCTIONS: Have generally been received well, TD Securities notes, even though recent 10-year sale was soft. TD notes that takedown statistics show investment funds continuing to take increasing allotments in recent months (54% of April supply). "Despite Treasury's decision not to cut coupon auction sizes later this year, we believe the Fed's open market purchases of Treasuries to replace MBS runoff later this year will help buoy the market," TD says.      

* 7-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen says the 7-year sector trades fair on the curve vs 5s and 10s, and trades slightly rich against older 7s from a relative value standpoint. The bank notes that the WI is trading beneath all prior auction high yields since September 2017, which is a negative; and accordingly, will likely need to see concession going into the auction on an outright basis. The previous 7-year auction was poor, tailing. However, dealer holdings in the 6- to 7-year bucket are the lowest since October 2018, and may provide marginal support for the auction.

content:
NZD/AUD/CAD

The Kiwi continues to highlight the extent of risk aversion in major currency circles, but has also been undermined by a bleak NZ business outlook via the latest NBNZ survey and cross-flows back into the Aussie that appears to be defying heightened US-China trade jitters or at least the bulk of the anxiety. Indeed, Nzd/Usd is inching nearer 0.6500 from just over 0.6550, and Aud/Nzd is extending its rebound from around 1.0575 to circa 1.0625 as Aud/Usd holds closer to the middle of its 0.6912-31 range. Conversely, the Loonie breached support between 1.3521-24 to test psychological resistance and offers in the 1.3550 area post-BoC and removal of the line about returning to a neutral rate before fading and perhaps reflecting on other more encouraging elements of the accompanying statement. To recap, the benchmark rate was maintained at 1.75%, as universally expected and the BoC contended that recent data has reinforced the governing council’s view that the late 2018 slowdown was temporary, while headline inflation is seen staying around target in coming months and core measures also remain close to the 2% goal. On the flip-side, trade restrictions are having direct effect on Canadian exports and as risks on this front have risen the current level of policy accommodation is deemed appropriate.

EUR

The single currency finally filled stops through 1.1150 vs the Dollar, but was also undermined by weaker than expected German jobs data (even allowing for classification changes), ongoing Italian political and fiscal issues, alongside a test of 0.8800 against Sterling around the Frankfurt fix before oaring some losses ahead of 1.1135 support in Eur/Usd.

GBP/CHF/JPY

All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as the Pound pivoted 1.2650 and benefited from the aforementioned Euro cross move, but remained hampered by the ongoing UK political hiatus and related interlude in Brexit bargaining into the October 31st Article 50 deadline. Meanwhile, the Franc retreated from 1.0050 and Yen faltered ahead of 109.00 where 1 bn expiries sat and extended to 109.15, as the Buck also derived impetus from a degree of safe-haven demand - DXY back over 98.000 and inching closer to 2019 peaks set last week (98.373 vs 98.127 at best so far today).

NOK/SEK

Mixed fortunes for the Scandi Crowns as Eur/Nok rebounded to 9.7750+ amidst another retreat in oil prices, but Eur/Sek was capped around 10.7000 after significantly stronger than forecast Swedish Q1 GDP data (largely due to a healthy export contribution vs depressed domestic consumption however).

EM

A broad sea of red across the region on a mixture of usual and well documented negative factors, but the Real bucked the broad bearish trend awaiting pension reform bill progress and details of a forthcoming growth pact pencilled for signing during the week starting June 10th. However, Usd/Brl also held below the 4.0000 marker after the BcB announced capital measures to be unveiled next week.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt off best levels, but still in demand, while DXY nudges 98.000 again
content: It’s still panning out like yesterday for bonds, with the glaring exception of BTPs that have recovered relatively well from their latest Italian fiscal frailty to regain the 130.00 level from near multi-month chart support more than a full point below, albeit in sync with Spanish Bonos that are tipped to outperform into/over month end on above average duration demand. Back to the core, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are all consolidating off peaks, but retain a firm underlying bid awaiting the Wall Street open to see if the global equity market slide turns full circle. Similarly, the Dollar is holding a firm line with just the ultimate safe-havens outpacing the Usd.

Huawei warned that the US ban could hit up to 1200 US suppliers, particularly cyber security vendors, the FT reported. Huawei purchased roughly USD 11bln worth of good and services from US companies last year.

DOW

Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – A Washington Post investigation found that many iOS apps use the iPhone’s background refresh feature to send data (such as location and IP address) to third-party tracker companies, raising questions about Apple's promises on user privacy.

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – IATA head de Juniac said that the 737 MAX could remain grounded for another two months, according to the WSJ. Elsewhere, Ethiopian Airlines pilot von Hoesslin reportedly told senior managers at the airline that additional training and improved communication to crew members was needed, several months prior to the first Boeing (BA) 737 Max crash, as according to previously unreported correspondences to the airline. In other news, Boeing CEO, when speaking at a conference, commented that he expects the 787 to be significant margin and cash tailwind for the aircraft maker and that long-term prospects and production demand for the 737 MAX had not changed, whilst also saying they had made progress regarding returning the grounded 737 MAX to the skies. Boeing officials also noted that the co. won’t reinstate guidance until the 737 MAX grounding is over.

DowDuPont (DWDP) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) said that no portion of the impairment charges incurred this quarter relate to future cash expenditures. The industrial conglomerate said the charges will be in the range of USD 0.8bln-1.3bln on a pre-tax basis, before reaffirming their FY19 guidance.

Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) has appointed three new executives in Asia and New York to its management committee, a move which they say reflects the importance of the AsiaPac region to their business strategy.

Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced full enrolment into a proof-of-concept efficacy study of an investigational HIV preventative vaccine.

Microsoft’s (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) LinkedIn has acquired Drawbridge, a start-up company that helps companies with identity management using machine learning, saying the co. may help to enhance LinkedIn’s Marketing Solutions platform. 

NASDAQ 100

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – New York City Mayor Blasio said the ecommerce giant will not receive any help from the city should it choose to end its plans to move to Manhattan. Elsewhere, Twitch, a live streaming site owned by Amazon, has disabled the ability for new users to stream live after a “troll attack” on part of the site.

Amgen (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is launching Amgen Community Oncology Research Collaborations, teaming up with community oncology networks to create a new initiative to enhance access by community centres to innovative oncology clinical research.

CSX Corp’s (CSX) (Industrials/Railroads) CFO Lonegro is to leave the company and be replaced by Boone, who will serve as interim CFO.

Facebook’s (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) user engagement is set to stagnate or decline in the foreseeable future, according to Mashable, with daily time spent on the site having fallen to 38 minutes in 2018 (from 41 minutes in 2017).

Google (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) temporary workers, including temps, vendors and contractors (known internally as TVCs), now outnumber full-time employees, according to the NYT, raising questions regarding employee treatment at the tech giant. Reportedly, TVCs often accept the role with the hope of securing a full-time gig.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – New York University professor Scott Galloway, who predicted Amazon’s acquisition of Wholesale Foods, has predicted a buyout of Tesla within the next 12 months and also predicts, in that time period, the automaker’s share price will fall below USD 100.

T-Mobile (TMUS), Sprint (S) (Communications Services/Wireless Telecommunications Services) – The two telecoms co.s may sell their prepaid wireless service brand, Boost Mobile, for up to USD 3bln. This sale may come as part of the concessions the two co.s offered in order to gain approval for their merger.

S&P 500

Capri Holdings Ltd (CPRI) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) (USD) report Q1 19 EPS 0.63 (exp. 0.61), Revenue 1.344 (exp. 1.33bln). FY EPS view 4.95 (exp. 4.95), FY Revenue view 6bln (exp. 5.22bln).

Dow’s (DOW) (Materials/Commodity Chemicals) Corteva (CTVA) will replace Fluor (FLR) (Industrials/Construction & Engineering) on the S&P500 as of the commencement of trading on 3 June.

General Mills (GIS) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) has been cut to Sell from Neutral at Goldman Sachs, where analyst Jason English cites a deceleration of growth ahead which had previously benefitted from the Blue Buffalo acquisition and “sequential improvement in the co.’s core business”.

Honeywell International’s (HON) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) Aerospace unit began using an online marketplace based on blockchain earlier this year that enabled trade between over 800 international buyers and sellers of Aerospace equipment in real time, according to the WSJ.

Morgan Stanley (MS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) is to cut roughly half a dozen Asian equity jobs as part of a global cost cutting initiative.

Newmont Goldcorp Corp (NEM) (Materials/Gold) – Mexican authorities hope to resolve a dispute in Mexico’s Zacateca’s state between the mining corp. and locals that has resulted in a 2-month blockade at the Penasquito gold mine.

OTHER

Arcelor Mittal (MT) (Materials/Metals & Mining) announced plans for a further round of European production cuts, as the steel manufacturer looks to further align production with current levels of demand, putting up to 25k jobs at risk.

Bed Bath and Beyond (BBBY) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced the appointment of 4 new members to its board, whilst entering into an agreement with an investor group, who have withdrawn their 10 nominees for the board. Moreover, a member of the investor group withdrew litigation filed against BBBY.

Ericsson (ERIC-B SS, ERIC) (Information Technology/Communications Equipment) and Nokia (NOKIA FH, NOK) (Information Technology/Communications Equipment) are reportedly jostling to take advantage of the US political campaign against Huawei, as they look to secure equipment swap contracts or deals that replace Huawei 5G upgrades. Specifically, Softbank picked the two European tech firms for their 5G rollout.

HEICO Corp (HEI) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) (USD) reports Q1 19 EPS 0.60 (exp. 0.49), Revenue 0.516bln (exp. 0.48bln).

HSBC (HSBC) (Financials/Banks) announced plans to increase its employment count in its Asian retail wealth management division by roughly 300 people.

Nissan (7201 JT, NSANY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) says it is not opposed to the Renualt (RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles)/Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) merger.

Toyota Motors (TM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) are reportedly to invest Yuan 50bln in China’s Didi Chuxing, a ride hailing company.

Volkswagen’s (VOW3 GY, VLKAY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) head of its Porsche’s (PAH3 GY, POAHY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) unit is under investigation by German prosecutors over a possible breach of fiduciary trust involving payments made to a Porsche works council member.

Workday Inc (WDAY) (Information Technology/Software) (USD) reports Q1 19 EPS 0.43 (exp. 0.41), revenue 0.825bln (exp. 0.81bln), raises FY20 subscription revenue to 3.045-3.06bln from 3.03-3.045bln.

Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) CEO Khosrowshahi said that the ride-hailing co will not achieve profitability for the next year or two, but that will come.

subject: Morgan Stanley says recession risks are rising, and warns that the Fed might fall 'behind the curve'
content: The bank says as recession risks are rising globally, the Fed may fall behind the curve, taking comfort from stable US labour market and consumer sector conditions. "Despite the strong reading of May Conference Board consumer confidence, the US equity market broke below key support levels, the US yield curve deepened its inversion (now increasingly affecting the belly of the yield curve), and the US 10-year real yield marked a new year-to-date low at 51bp while US inflation breakeven rates continued to push lower. The financial markets' verdict seems clear – recession is coming"

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.6%] are firmly in negative territory, as the risk-off sentiment spills over from the Asia-Pac session
  • US Treasury’s currency report stated that no major trading partner met the currency manipulation list; but 9 countries, including China, have been placed on the watchlist
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, BoC Rate Decision, ECB’s Visco, supply from the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly lower following the headwinds from US where all major indices declined on return from the extended weekend and in which the E-mini S&P eventually broke below the 2800 level. The weakness was attributed to lingering trade tensions after Chinese press pointed the blame on US for the recent breakdown in talks and as the outspoken Global Times Editor suggested China is seriously considering restricting rare earth exports to the US. ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) were negative with broad weakness seen across nearly all sectors in Australia and with financials subdued by the recent declines in global yields, while currency strength added to the pressures for Tokyo stocks. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) declined amid the trade uncertainty and as early data indicators reportedly suggested China’s economy weakened this month, although the losses were cushioned by a substantial liquidity operation of CNY 270bln which resulted to the PBoC’s largest daily net injection since mid-January. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the upside in global counterparts amid declining yields and the negative risk sentiment, which lifted prices of the Japanese 10yr benchmark to above 153.00 and its best level since early April.

PBoC injected CNY 270bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 250bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8988 (Prev. 6.8973

Chinese Foreign Ministry hopes that US will refrain from conducting unilateral assessments of other countries currency levels, and that the US is not in a position to decide which countries manipulate currencie. (Newswires)

US

 

US Treasury said no major trading partner met currency manipulation list but added that China, Germany, Japan, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore and Vietnam warrant placement on its currency monitoring list (Switzerland and India were removed). Furthermore, it lowered 2 thresholds used to designate FX manipulators and urged China to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Reports suggest UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn is reportedly ready to back a 2nd Brexit referendum and may announce backing it within days. (The Mirror)

UK PM May says Brexit is now a matter for her successor, which indicates PM May will not put the WA to a vote in Parliament next week. (Newswires)

UK HoC Speaker Bercow said he has no plans to stand down as Speaker of the House of Commons, despite speculation that he would retire this summer. The Guardian infers that this moves risks angering hardline Eurosceptics who believe he wants to thwart a no-deal Brexit. (BBC/Guardian)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt is losing support to Environment Secretary Gove after stating yesterday that seeking a policy of leaving without a deal would be political suicide, though he has previously said he would chose no-deal over no-Brexit; subsequently, MP’s have reportedly stated they are no longer backing Hunt, with some switching to supporting Gove. (Times)

CBI stated that business and professional services companies reported the steepest drop in work volume since August 2012 and were extremely negative regarding outlook for year ahead. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said the EU summit on top jobs was good and harmonious, while she wants the Commission President candidate settled by the June summit. (Newswires) However, reports suggest that German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron are at odds over appointments for top jobs within the EU with Macron continuing to resist Merkel’s suggestion of Manfred Weber for EU Commission President, suggesting EU Chief Negotiator Barnier as a potential compromise candidate. (Newswires) Note, a formal decision will be made at the June 20-21st EU summit.

Italian PM Conte is reportedly seeking support from Deputy PM Salvini to maintain current government coalition. Separately, 5 Star Senator Paragone is reportedly to offer resignation it Italian Deputy PM Di Maio. (Newswires)

ECB Financial Stability report states that challenges to financial stability are increasing amid downside risks to the economic outlook.

- Economic recovery in the Euro area has been delayed but not derailed

- Corporate bond markets and liquidity conditions remain fragile despite bond price recovery in 2019

ECB’s Mersch (Hawkish) states that as central banks we must remain true to the core mandate, the capacity to adapt to evolving needs must be retained but this must not come at the expense of independence or accountability. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn (Neutral) says that the ECB should review their monetary policy strategy in the medium and long term; at some point a strategy review is needed, but he would not touch the ECB mandate; need credible guidance and backed up if needed. Should look at the definition of price stability, view is that 2% is not a ceiling. And that it is no secrete they have discussed negative rates impact, on the idea of of ECB guaranteeing Govt. debt, says central banks are forbidden from monetary financing. Iranian President Rouhani says the door to discussions with the US is not closed as long as they lift sanctions on Iran and fulfills its commitments. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are lower across the board [Eurostoxx -1.6%] following on from a downbeat session in Asia as sentiment took the queue from Wall Street after the E-Mini S&P took out the 2800 level to the downside. Sectors are all in the red with IT names lagging after Huawei signalled that it is pressing ahead with its lawsuit against the US government as US-China tech tensions intensify. Defensive stocks such as utilities and healthcare names are somewhat faring better, albeit still in the red. In terms of individual movers, ProsiebentSat1 (+4.0%) spiked higher amid reports that Mediaset (-0.8%) are to purchase a 9.1% stake in the company, which would grant 9.9% of voting rights, although Mediaset noted that they do not seek board representation. Elsewhere, Casino (-4.6%) shares slid after the company announced that it will not pay an interim dividend this year, whilst S&P downgraded its credit after its parent company entered French safeguard procedures. Finally, ArcelorMittal (-4.0%) opened lower by as much as 7% after cutting production guidance in Europe amid weak market demand. In light of the recent sell-off in stocks amid trade woes, Nomura believe that the downside can be seen as orderly and sentiment is not out of control. The analysts state that the recent sell off in equities is being fuelled by transient stock selling via speculative players and a seasonal rise in volatility, as global equities pass through a predictable second wave of selling. Following the E-mini S&P’s declined below 2800, eyes turn to the cash market at the US open where Nomura warns that “CTAs have been pressed to close out long positions and cut their losses once the S&P 500 broke below 2,820”, but CTAs have already unwound over 80% of their longs, thus the risk of a chain reaction sell-off has diminished.

FX

CHF/JPY/USD - The Franc’s resurgence or rebound from yesterday’s lows seems symptomatic of the wider safe-haven demand and deeper risk-off sentiment. Usd/Chf has retreated towards 1.0050 again vs a fraction shy of 1.0100 at one stage on Tuesday, while Eur/Chf is drifting back down to 1.1200 compared to almost 1.1280, albeit with the single currency under pressure independently on the back of latest bleak German data – see below. Usd/Jpy has also recoiled to retest key Fib support ahead of 109.00 at 109.23 (Fib retracement level) having bounced firmly to just over 109.60, but decent option expiry interest may prop up the headline pair (1 bn between 109.00-15) on top of anticipated buying interest at the big figure. Note also, the Buck has extended its recovery in wake of upbeat US consumer confidence and with the aid of gains vs riskier/high beta currencies, with the DXY back above 98.000, albeit just and eyeing last week’s 98.373 ytd best within a 98.043-97.861 range.

NZD/CAD/GBP/AUD/EUR - All softer vs the Greenback, and with the Kiwi underperforming after the latest RBNZ FSR and NBNZ business survey showing that expectations remain weak. Nzd/Usd has slipped back below 0.6550 to around 0.6515, with the Aud/Nzd cross climbing over 1.0600 again even though the Aussie is also struggling to retain 0.6900+ status following yet another uber dovish RBA call overnight as JPM is now predicting a total of 100 bp worth of easing by mid-2020. Elsewhere, the Loonie is really trading on the defensive as the clock ticks down to a potentially dovish BoC with Usd/Cad not far from 1.3520+ late April peaks and options pricing a circa 53 pip break-even over the event – see our policy meeting preview on the Research Suite. Meanwhile, Cable is slipping further from 1.2700 towards the big figure below as another Tory leadership hopeful joins the list and the EU stresses no renegotiation of the WA, and Eur/Usd is hovering just above 1.1150 stops having failed to hold above the 30 DMA (1.1191) again. Note, a shock jump in German unemployment and uptick in the jobless rate that was only partly mitigated by a reclassification of the labour force also weighed on the Euro as noted above.

NOK/SEK - Divergence between the Scandi Crowns as Eur/Nok rebounds through 9.7500 amidst another retreat in oil prices (that may also be niggling the Cad), but Eur/Sek is capped around 10.7000 after significantly stronger than forecast Swedish Q1 GDP data (largely due to a healthy export contribution vs depressed domestic consumption however).

EM - Contrasting fortunes for the Lira and Rand as well, like yesterday, as Usd/Try revisits 6.0000, but Usd/Zar pivots 14.8000 within 14.8900-7000 parameters on a further fall-out from SA political developments and the return of Mabuza to Ramaphosa’s fold.

Swedish GDP QQ (Q1) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.2%

FIXED INCOME

Not quite déjà vu, but 10 year benchmarks have eased back from best levels ahead of the halfway stage in Europe as they did on Tuesday. However, Bunds remain in positive territory despite a strong Bono-led rebound across the Eurozone periphery including BTPs and relatively close to the 168.00 handle after a strong Bobl sale, while Gilts set a fresh Liffe high of 129.58 (+30 ticks) before losing momentum and US Treasuries are hugging the peaks of overnight session ranges after the 10 year note topped out at 125-24+ vs Fib resistance at 125-27. Note, the 10 year US yield has breached 2.25% and 7 year cash is sub-2.15% ahead of tonight’s supply that is normally well received by indirect bidders that comprise overseas buyers, but could conceivably see less demand from China due to ongoing trade/diplomatic strains, along with other foreign sponsors ruffled by the latest/longer list of names on the US FX manipulation list.

COMMODITIES

WTI (-2.3%) and Brent (-2.0%) futures continue to free-fall amidst the risk-off tone in the market, with the former extending loses below the psychological USD 58.00/bbl and under its 100 DMA at USD 58.46/bbl. Similarly, its Brent counterpart trades south of the USD 69/bbl level and closer to the USD 68.50/bbl mark. News flows has been relatively light in the complex although the Druzhba pipeline will be pumping clean oil to Hungary as of 1700BST following the halt in operations amid contaminated oil from Russia in mid-April. Turning to OPEC, ahead the upcoming meeting of the cartel (date yet to be confirmed), Kazakhstan’s Energy Minister noted that it stands ready to join the extension of the global oil cut deal if the decision in taken. On that front, Russia’s First Deputy PM noted that they will consider an extension to the deal but have arguments in favour and against an extension, adding that Moscow will continue to weight the arguments. Finally, as a reminder, the API crude inventory data will be released tonight due to US’ market absence on Monday, and thus the EIA release has been delayed until tomorrow.

Over in the metal complex, gold (+0.4%) continues to rise despite a firmer USD as investors flee to the safe haven amid the current risk aversion; meanwhile, copper (-0.8%) falls in tandem with the risk tone. Further for the red metal, workers at the Chilean Chuquicamata copper mine of have been voting on a potential strike after labour unions rejected management’s final offer on wages. The results of the vote are expected this evening.

ANALYSIS: US Treasury's Semi-Annual FX Report
content:
• Released overnight (and a month late), the report did not name any country (China) a currency manipulator. However, it added Ireland, Italy, Vietnam, Singapore and Malaysia to its monitoring list, which already includes China, Japan, South Korea and Germany. Switzerland and India have been removed from the monitoring list, as was expected. The Treasury also expanded the number of US trading partners covered in the report from 12 to 21. 
  • A key takeaway was that the Treasury adjusted its three criteria for judging whether a nation is a currency manipulator (indeed, the Treasury justified the delay due to changes to the criteria); two of the thresholds that the Treasury uses were revised lower (current account balance criteria lowered to 2%/GDP vs 3% previously), and persistence of net FX purchases (lowered to six out of 12 months vs eight out of 12 months previously). 
  • The report, however, unsurprisingly remained critical of China (which only met one of the three criteria), and the nation remains at the top of the monitoring list; The Treasury stated that “China’s persistent and widespread use of non-tariff barriers, nonmarket mechanisms, state subsidies, and other discriminatory measures that are increasingly distorting China’s trading and investment relationships” to “refrain from engaging in competitive devaluation and to not target China’s exchange rate for competitive purposes.” The Treasury recommitted to continuing bilateral engagement with China.

Source: UOB

Nomura quants state that whilst sentiment is being weighed upon by the further inversion of the 3m10yr curve and US-China tensions, the latest sell-off can be seen as orderly and sentiment is not out of control
content:
• They state that the recent sell off in equities is being fuelled by transient stock selling via speculative players and a seasonal rise in volatility, as global equities pass through a predictable second wave of selling
  • Most aggressive sales were noted by short-term trend-following algos, with CTAs pressed to cut their losses after the S&P broke below 2820. But with 80% of longs shed, a chain-reaction of selling is believed to be less likely, with the 2800 level in the S&P being where longs become fully squared away.
  • Even if CTAs turn to short positions in US equities, they don’t see them selling for long unless other players cascade in to trade upon expectations of a US recession
  • Risk-parity funds are rotating from DM stocks and commodities to investment grade bonds as part of month-end rebalancing, with May rebalancing estimated at just above USD 9bln
  • In FX, CTAs are building momentum for risk averse trade, with high beta currencies being sold and safe havens being bought, resulting in increased CTA shorts in USDJPY, whilst still adding longs in USDCNH

subject: Bunds: maintaining bullish momentum and probing above 168.00
content: The 10 year German benchmark has extended gains in line with US Treasuries as risk-off flows continue to propel core bonds to fresh highs, with 168.04 providing a degree of resistance as the corresponding yield approaches another psychological marker at -20 bp. The ongoing sell-off in global stocks ahead of month end is fuelling demand for fixed income, while Bunds are also deriving further support via weakness in Italian debt on renewed strains between the coalition Government and Brussels over Rome’s budget. Ahead, more Eurozone data, ECB speakers and German supply in the form of Eur3 bn Bobls that should be gobbled up in the current environment, on paper at least unless the negative 55 bp or so rate is deemed too unattractive/punitive. Back to Eurex, the 10 year future has drifted back down towards the 167.90 low vs yesterday’s 167.80 close and from a technical perspective nearest support and resistance come in at 167.52 (Tuesday’s intraday base) and 168.13 (a continuation chart peak from mid-2016).

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly lower following the headwinds from US where all major indices declined on return from the extended weekend and in which the E-mini S&P eventually broke below the 2800 level. The weakness was attributed to lingering trade tensions after Chinese press pointed the blame on US for the recent breakdown in talks and as the outspoken Global Times Editor suggested China is seriously considering restricting rare earth exports to the US. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were negative with broad weakness seen across nearly all sectors in Australia and with financials subdued by the recent declines in global yields, while currency strength added to the pressures for Tokyo stocks. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) declined amid the trade uncertainty and as early data indicators reportedly suggested China’s economy weakened this month, although the losses were cushioned by a substantial liquidity operation of CNY 270bln which resulted to the PBoC’s largest daily net injection since mid-January.

FTSE

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Co. plans to add 300 wealth management staff in Asia this year and plans to sharpen its focus on Singapore. (Newswires)

UK homebuilders – London homebuyers are getting the largest discounts in at least six years, according to data compiled by Zoopla. (Newswires)

Oil names – WTI crude futures fell back below the USD 59.00/bbl level in a continuation of this week’s choppy price action and Brent crude retreated from USD 70/bbl amid touted book squaring

Mining names - Gold prices were marginally underpinned by safe-haven demand, while copper was subdued by the downbeat sentiment and as Chinese benchmark iron ore futures pulled back from record levels.

OTHER UK COMPANIES

WHSmith (SMWH LN) – Co. have been voted the UK’s worst high street shop, according to a Which survey for the second year; with the Co. being in the bottom two in the survey for nine consecutive years. (Evening Standard)

BROKER MOVES

SERCO GROUP (SRP LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. reportedly wants to avoid capital increases during the restructuring of its investment bank, adding that it may consider lowering capital buffer, according to several sources (Newswires) This is in-fitting with the Handelsblatt article published in market hours yesterday.

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Knorr Bremse (KBX GY) – Q1 EBITDA EUR 333.7mln vs. Prev. EUR 295mln. Revenue EUR 1.76bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.61bln. Co raises FY19 revenue and EBITDA margin guidance. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BEIERSDORF (BEI GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BANKHAUS LAMPE

CAC

Renault (RNO FP)/ Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) - Nissan (7201 JT) is tentatively not against a merger between Renault and Fiat Chrysler. Furthermore, Renault is said to give approval for the Fiat Chrysler merger as soon as next week, according to sources. (Nikkei/Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Ethiopian Airlines pilot von Hoesslin reportedly told senior managers at the airline that additional training and improved communication to crew members was needed, several months prior to the first Boeing (BA) 737 Max crash; as according to previously unreported correspondences to the airline. (Newswires)

EDF (EDF FP) – CEO notes that the French government may have to consider lowering taxes on electricity. (Europe 1 Radio)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Casino (CO FP) – Co. announced that it will not pay an interim dividend in 2019. Separately, S&P lowered Casino’s rating to “B” CreditWatch Negative after its parent company entered French safeguard procedure. (Newswires)

Elior (ELIOR FP) – H1 revenue EUR 2.60bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.20bln. Adj. EBITDA EUR 122mln vs. Prev. EUR 131mln. Co. cuts FY19 organic growth forecast to -1% (Prev. above 1%). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ACCOR (AC FP) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT MAINFIRST

PAN EUROPE

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are subdued following on from their US counterparts where the E-mini S&P dropped below the 2800 level as US-China tensions remain a key trading theme
  • US Treasury released their currency report placing 9 countries, including China, on the watchlist but did not name any as manipulators
  • Looking ahead, highlights include French GDP, German Unemployment, BoC Rate Decision, ECB’s Weidmann, Mersch, Rehn & Visco, supply from Germany and the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly lower following the headwinds from US where all major indices declined on return from the extended weekend and in which the E-mini S&P eventually broke below the 2800 level. The weakness was attributed to lingering trade tensions after Chinese press pointed the blame on US for the recent breakdown in talks and as the outspoken Global Times Editor suggested China is seriously considering restricting rare earth exports to the US. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were negative with broad weakness seen across nearly all sectors in Australia and with financials subdued by the recent declines in global yields, while currency strength added to the pressures for Tokyo stocks. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) declined amid the trade uncertainty and as early data indicators reportedly suggested China’s economy weakened this month, although the losses were cushioned by a substantial liquidity operation of CNY 270bln which resulted to the PBoC’s largest daily net injection since mid-January. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the upside in global counterparts amid declining yields and the negative risk sentiment, which lifted prices of the Japanese 10yr benchmark to above 153.00 and its best level since early April.

PBoC injected CNY 270bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 250bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8988 (Prev. 6.8973) 

UK/EU

Further reports suggest UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn is reportedly ready to back a 2nd Brexit referendum and may announce backing it within days. (The Mirror)

UK PM May says Brexit is now a matter for her successor, which indicates PM May will not put the WA to a vote in Parliament next week. (Newswires)

UK HoC Speaker Bercow said he has no plans to stand down as Speaker of the House of Commons, despite speculation that he would retire this summer. The Guardian infers that this moves risks angering hardline Eurosceptics who believe he wants to thwart a no-deal Brexit. (BBC/Guardian)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt is losing support to Environment Secretary Gove after stating yesterday that seeking a policy of leaving without a deal would be political suicide, though he has previously said he would chose no-deal over no-Brexit; subsequently, MP’s have reportedly stated they are no longer backing Hunt, with some switching to supporting Gove. (Times)

CBI stated that business and professional services companies reported the steepest drop in work volume since August 2012 and were extremely negative regarding outlook for year ahead. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said the EU summit on top jobs was good and harmonious, while she wants the Commission President candidate settled by the June summit. (Newswires) However, reports suggest that German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron are at odds over appointments for top jobs within the EU with Macron continuing to resist Merkel’s suggestion of Manfred Weber for EU Commission President, suggesting EU Chief Negotiator Barnier as a potential compromise candidate. (Newswires) Note, a formal decision will be made at the June 20-21st EU summit.

UK BRC Shop Price Index (May) Y/Y 0.8% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)

 

FX

 

DXY was steady overnight and remained within close proximity to retest the 98.00 level to the upside after having found support from better than expected US Consumer Confidence data, while its major counterparts traded subdued after EUR/USD and GBP/USD recently failed attempts to reclaim the 1.1200 and 1.2700 handles respectively. Elsewhere, the risk averse tone dampened USD/JPY and early upside in antipodeans was thwarted as the Australian 10yr yield dropped below the RBA Cash Rate Target of 1.5% and with JPMorgan calling for 4 rate cuts by the RBA to 0.50% by mid-2020, while NZD/USD was lacklustre after the RBNZ Financial Stability Report proved to be a non-event and as Business Confidence data remained at a contraction. CNH also marginally softened as the PBoC continued to set the mid-point closer towards 6.9000 and after the US Treasury released its long-awaited currency report in which it refrained from naming any countries as currency manipulators but placed 9 in its monitoring list including China (others included Ireland, Italy, Vietnam, Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, South Korea and Germany; Switzerland and India were removed) which it urged to avoid a persistently weak currency.

RBNZ Financial Stability Report said the financial system remains resilient to a broad range of economic risks but added that risks remain elevated and are largely unchanged in the past 6 months. Furthermore, it stated that there is a need for some insurers and non-bank deposit takers to improve capital buffers and that current LVR settings remain appropriate, while further easing in LVR is subject to continuing subdued credit and house price growth. (Newswires)

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (May) -32.0 (Prev. -37.5). (Newswires) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (May) 8.5 (Prev. 7.1)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly lower amid the risk avers tone with WTI crude futures back below the USD 59.00/bbl level in a continuation of this week’s choppy price action and Brent crude retreated from USD 70/bbl amid touted book squaring due to option expiries yesterday, while focus turns to the holiday-delayed inventory reports beginning with API stockpiles due after-hours in today’s US session. Conversely, gold prices were marginally underpinned by safe-haven demand, while copper was subdued by the downbeat sentiment and as Chinese benchmark iron ore futures pulled back from record levels.

Chile's Codelco said the US-China trade war has a "phenomenal" impact on copper and that the volatility makes investment decisions harder, while it sees copper demand growing 1.8% and supply growing 1.6% in 2021. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US State Department said it is alarmed by Russian and Syrian government airstrikes in North West Syria, while it also commented that the entire weapons of mass destruction programme in North Korea violates the UN resolution. (AFP/Newswires)

US is considering suspending training for Turkish pilots on F-35 fighter jets due to Ankara's plan to buy Russian air defence system, according to sources. (Newswires) 

US

The Tplex traded directionally higher on Tuesday, with new contract highs made in Ultra longs, USM9s, Ultras and TYM9s. Looking at the curve, the belly saw the largest fall in yields, with 7-year yields posting 19-month lows; the front-to-belly saw curve flattening with the 2s/10s spread settling c. 2bps flatter, whereas the 10/s/30s steepened by c. 1.3bps. Elsewhere, the US 2-year auction was solid, stopped through the screens by 1bps (high yield 2.125%). Cover was firm at 2.75x (highest since August 2018), above recent averages and the previous. Dealer take down fell beneath recent averages as well as the prior (26.2%, the lowest since Jan 2018vs 36.1% six-auction average), leaving directs with 27.2% (largest since May 2016, six auction average 16.4%), and indirects with 46.6% (slightly beneath the 47.6% six-auction average). The 5-year auction was more in line with recent auctions, stopping through the screens by 0.2bps on a high yield of 2.065% (lowest yield since October 2017), covered 2.38x (six auction average 2.36x). Dealers took a touch below recent averages at 24.2% (largest share since January, six auction average 26.3%), directs took 18.4% (highest since February, and up from 15% six-auction average), leaving indirects with 57.5% (a shade beneath the 58.6% six-auction average). US T-note futures (M9) settled 16 ticks higher at 125-12+.

US Treasury said no major trading partner met currency manipulation list but added that China, Germany, Japan, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore and Vietnam warrant placement on its currency monitoring list (Switzerland and India were removed). Furthermore, it lowered 2 thresholds used to designate FX manipulators and urged China to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. (Newswires)

FOMC Discount Rate Minutes stated that all 12 Fed regional banks supported keeping discount rates steady before 30th April meeting and that no sentiment was expressed for changing the rate, while directors said the FOMC should continue with patience on rate moves. (Newswires)

Canadian Government is to formally present a bill to its parliament on the ratification of the USMCA on Wednesday, according to a source. (Newswires)
